{{Infobox musical artist | name = Freddie Roulette | image = Freddie_Roulette_creative_commons_wikipedia.png| caption | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Frederick Martin Roulette | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1939|5|3|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Evanston, Illinois]], [[United States]] | death_date = | death_place = | instrument = [[Lap steel guitar]] | genre = [[Chicago blues]], [[electric blues]] | occupation = [[Guitarist]] | years_active = 1960s–present | label = [[Janus Records|Janus]], [[Rykodisc]], various | associated_acts = Daphne Blue / Ray Bronner [[Henry Kaiser (musician)|Henry Kaiser]], [[Harvey Mandel]], [[Earl Hooker]], [[The Holmes Brothers]] | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''Frederick Martin "Freddie" Roulette''' (born May 3, 1939) is an [[United States|American]] [[electric blues]] [[lap steel guitar]]ist and singer. He is best known as an exponent of the [[lap steel guitar]]. Roulette is also a member of the Daphne Blue band,{{cite web|url=http://vidstatsx.com/daphneblueband/youtube-channel |title=Daphneblueband YouTube Channel Stats, Subscriber Statistics, Ranking |publisher=Vidstatsx.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-12}} and has collaborated with [[Earl Hooker]], [[Charlie Musselwhite]], [[Henry Kaiser (musician)|Henry Kaiser]], and [[Harvey Mandel]], and released several solo [[album]]s.{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p120588|pure_url=yes}}|title=Freddie Roulette |author=Craig Harris |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=October 16, 2011}} One commentator described Roulette as an "excellent musician".{{cite book | first= Gérard | last= Herzhaft et al | year= 1997 | title= Encyclopedia of the blues | edition= 1st | publisher= The University of Arkansas Press | location= Fayetteville, Arkansas | isbn= 1-55728-452-0 | page= 32}} As of August 12, 2013, VidStatsX, a video statistic company, reported Freddie Roulette's work with the Daphne Blue band shows approximately 55,000 views on the video sharing site, [[YouTube]].{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8Qh7ELzF_P0 |title=Freddie Roulette Lap Steel Master (Behind the scenes making a Daphne Blue album) |publisher=YouTube |date=2010-11-13 |accessdate=2013-08-12}}{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=72OASdHYN0Y |title=Freddie Roulette & Daphne Blue SLEEPWALK LIVE Santo Johnny |publisher=YouTube |date=2007-09-27 |accessdate=2013-08-12}} ==Biography== Freddie Roulette's family originally came from [[New Orleans]],Scott M. Bock, ''Freddie Roulette: "I just decided steel was it"'', ''[[Juke Blues]]'' no. 61, 2006, pp.16-21 however he was born and raised in [[Evanston, Illinois]]. He learned to play steel guitar in high school. He started playing in clubs in [[Chicago]] in his teens, and in 1965 began work in Earl Hooker's backing band, continuing to tour and perform with him until 1969.{{cite book | first= Sebastian | last= Danchin | year= 2001 | title= Earl Hooker, blues master | edition= 1st | publisher= University Press of Mississippi | location= Jackson, Mississippi | isbn= 1-57806-306-X | page= 230 | url=http://books.google.com/books?id=-G76U3ikkFAC&pg=PA108#v=onepage&q&f=false}} Earl Hooker's band, with pianist [[Pinetop Perkins]], harmonica player [[Carey Bell]], vocalist Andrew Odom, and Roulette, was "widely acclaimed" and "considered [as] one of the best Earl had ever carried with him".{{cite book | first= Sebastian | last= Danchin | year= 2001 | title= Earl Hooker, blues master | edition= 1st | publisher= University Press of Mississippi | location= Jackson, Mississippi | isbn= 1-57806-306-X | page= 251 | url=http://books.google.com/books?id=-G76U3ikkFAC&pg=PA108#v=onepage&q&f=false}} Roulette participated on several of Hooker's singles, his 1967 album, ''The Genius of Earl Hooker'', and the 1969 follow-up, ''Two Bugs and a Roach''.{{cite web |url=http://www.wirz.de/music/hookefrm.htm |title=Illustrated Earl Hooker discography |author=Stefan Wirz |date= |work= |publisher=Wirz.de |accessdate=October 16, 2011}} Roulette later developed a friendship with Charlie Musselwhite, and recorded with him (credited as Fred Roulette) on the 1969 band album ''Chicago Blue Stars''.[http://www.allmusic.com/artist/the-chicago-blue-stars-p37885 ''Chicago Blue Stars'' at Allmusic.com] He then toured with Musselwhite, and backed him on the albums ''Tennessee Woman'' and ''Memphis, Tennessee'', before relocating to the [[San Francisco]], [[California]], area where he has lived ever since. When there, he played in a band with [[Luther Tucker]], and recorded with Earl Hooker's cousin, [[John Lee Hooker]]. In 1973, Roulette released his debut solo album, ''Sweet Funky Steel'', which was [[record producer|produced]] by his fellow guitarist, [[Harvey Mandel]]. [[Don "Sugarcane" Harris]] also played on several tracks. Over the next twenty years, he continued to perform with other musicians and occasionally led his own band, while also working full-time as an apartment manager. The 1996 album, ''Psychedelic Guitar Circus'', saw him work in a group format with Mandel, Kaiser and [[Steve Kimock]].{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r254257/credits|pure_url=yes}} |title=Allmusic ((( ''Psychedelic Guitar Circus'' > Credits )))}} His solo 1997 album, ''Back in Chicago: Jammin' with Willie Kent and the Gents'', had Roulette recording with both [[Willie Kent]] and [[Chico Banks]].{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r314275/credits|pure_url=yes}} |title=Allmusic ((( ''Back in Chicago: Jammin' with Willie Kent and the Gents'' > Credits )))}} The album won the ''[[Living Blues]]'' magazine award as Best Blues Album of 1997. Following that album's success, Roulette began performing widely at blues festivals, and followed it up with the 1998 album ''Spirit of Steel'', featuring [[The Holmes Brothers]] and produced by Kaiser, as well as contributing to Kaiser's own album ''Yo Miles'', a tribute to [[Miles Davis]]. Roulette's solo album, ''Man of Steel'' (2006), incorporated guitar playing contributions from [[Will Bernard]] and [[David Lindley (musician)|David Lindley]], as well as guitar and production duties from Kaiser.{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r849996/credits|pure_url=yes}} |title=Allmusic ((( ''Man of Steel'' > Credits )))}} It was recorded in [[Fantasy Studios]], in [[Berkeley, California]], and included strains of [[jazz]], [[country music|country]], [[soul music|soul]] and [[reggae]] in the overall blues setting.{{cite web |url=http://www.tradition-moderne.com/eng.php/page/content:artist_a_cd/cd_id/46/artist_id/b415c596671bf4c6d8f378ffaf7a2918/sid/83810f632bb39fef7c913f39ce214e38 |title=''Man of Steel'' (2006) |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Tradition-moderne.com |accessdate=October 16, 2011}} In the same year, Roulette played locally in a small combo including [[Mike Hinton]].{{cite web |url=http://www.hillbilly-music.com/hillbillymusicblog/2006_01_01_hillbilly-music_archive.html |title=Hillbilly Music |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Hillbilly-music.com |accessdate=October 16, 2011}} Roulette has played at a number of [[music festival|outdoor events]] over the years, including the [[Long Beach Blues Festival]], the [[San Francisco Blues Festival]] (1979), and the [[Calgary Folk Music Festival]] (2000). He has also continued to play club dates in the San Francisco area, often with Harvey Mandel. In 2012, ''Jammin' With Friends'' was recorded at three separate studios with various musicians. It was produced by Michael Borbridge, who also played drums on all the tracks. ==Discography== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year || Title || Record label |- | 1969 || ''Chicago Blue Stars''
with Charlie Musselwhite, Skip Rose, Louis Myers, Jack Myers, [[Fred Below]], Steve Kimock, Harvey Mandel|| style="text-align:center;"|[[Blue Thumb Records]] |- | 1973 || ''Sweet Funky Steel'' || style="text-align:center;"|[[Janus Records]] |- | 1996 || ''Psychedelic Guitar Circus''
with Henry Kaiser, Steve Kimock and Harvey Mandel|| style="text-align:center;"|[[Rykodisc|Rykodisc Records]] |- | 1997 || ''Back in Chicago: Jammin' with Willie Kent and the Gents'' || style="text-align:center;"|Hi Horse Records |- | 1999 || ''Spirit of Steel'' || style="text-align:center;"|Tradition & Moderne Records |- | 2000 || ''10 Picture Disk'' || style="text-align:center;"|Hi Horse Records |- | 2006 || ''Man of Steel'' || style="text-align:center;"|Tradition & Moderne Records |- | 2012 || ''Jammin' With Friends''|| style="text-align:center;"|Electric Snake |} {{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p120588/discography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Allmusic ((( Freddie Roulette > Discography > Main Albums )))}} ==See also== *[[List of electric blues musicians]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Persondata | NAME = Roulette, Freddie | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = [[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] and [[electric blues]] guitarist | DATE OF BIRTH = May 3, 1939 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Evanston, Illinois]], United States | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Roulette, Freddie}} [[Category:1939 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American blues musicians]] [[Category:American blues guitarists]] [[Category:Chicago blues musicians]] [[Category:Electric blues musicians]] [[Category:Musicians from Illinois]] [[Category:American session musicians]] [[Category:Slide guitarists]] [[Category:Steel guitarists]] [[Category:Slack-key guitarists]] [[Category:People from Evanston, Illinois]]
